moves.3... Bb4+ 4. Bd2 Bxd2+ 5. Nxd2: White is preparing e4 to support the big centre.
moves.7... Na6 8. Be2 Nc5 9. Qc2 h6: I wonder about 9 a5 to try to preserve the knight outpost at c5.
moves.11... d6 12. Qa4: Probably premature. White should have preferred castles but was I worried about g5 making sense of blacks ninth move 9 h6?
moves.12... Bd7: White saw 13 dc Bxc6 14 b5 but black has Bd7 and the pawn is pinned to whites queen.
moves.13. Qc2: The queen excursion was premature due to the above note.
moves.13... Rc8: This threatens a double capture against the pinned queen.
moves.14. Qb2: Moving out of the pin and the threat.
moves.15... Nf4 16. Nxd7 Nxe2 17. Qxg7 Kxd7 18: Whites manoeuvres have netted two pawns and the king can still castle.
moves.19... Rce8: I would prefer a rook on the g file aiming to deter white from kingside castling.
moves.20. O-O: Castling connects the two rooks and hopefully makes the king safe.
moves.20... Nb8 21. a4 Nd7 22. dxc6: Trying to get at the black king.
moves.24... Nc5: A good outpost for the knight.
moves.25. Rfb1: Both rooks are needed on the queen side where the black king is located.
moves.25... Kxc6: Not fatal but 25 Reb8 is preferable contesting the b file.25 Nxe4 is losing because of Rb7+ winning the queen.
moves.26. Nb3 Nxe4: A terrible move which loses immediately.
moves.27. Na5+: Black resigns. One way is mate. The other loses the queen.
